Post Text: From a packet of chips to detergent to personal care items - everything you can think of in the FMCG space is available in smaller packaging that will cost you somewhere between INR 1-20.But did you know that we didn't have the concept of sachets and smaller packaging introduced till the late 1970s?Back then even shampoo was considered a luxury because the salary of educated white-collar employees used to be around â‚¹1000 - 5000 a month and a bottle of 50 ml shampoo used to cost ~â‚¹40, making it unaffordable for most.Enter Late Shri R Chinnikrishnan who with his idea changed the trajectory of the FMCG sector.He didn't apply any rocket science, all he did was some simple math (jo hum sab school main seekhte hai).A 50 ml bottle cost around 40 bucks and on average a person uses 5ml for a single wash. So though they couldn't afford to pay 40 bucks in one go but they could pay 1-2 bucks which would be the per wash cost.And that's how sachets came into the pictureâ€”smaller packets with less stuff but super affordable.This made luxury items like shampoo affordable for many people. Soon, big companies like HUL and P&G also started selling their products in small packets, allowing them to tap into even the lowest economic class of the society.Now, in the present day, everything from chips to soap is available in small packets. These small packets have become a huge market, worth $9.76 billion in 2022. It's expected to keep growing at about 5.60% every year until 2028 when it might be worth $13.43 billion. That's how powerful a simple idea can be!Even at ZOFF, we are experimenting with smaller packaging.Now, look around you and name all the things that are in sachets/smaller packaging in the comments below!#d2c #zoff #fmcg #packaging #startup

Post Text: Did you know rats (yes, you read that right) were a game-changer in transforming how oil was packaged in India?Here is the story of Marico Limitedâ€™s Parachute oil.Today, Parachute has 54% of the market share in terms of the total volume of coconut oil sold in India. But it wasnâ€™t always like this.Letâ€™s go back to the 1970s when coconut oil was sold in metal containers. Since coconut oil was a commodity product, meaning that it had to be sold for consumption or production as it was found in nature, it was sold in bulk to retailers in tin containers.Maricoâ€™s Parachute Oil was already in the market but was viewed as a premium brand by traders. Why? Because Parachute had:ğŸ¥¥ A distinct aroma that set it apart &ğŸ¥¥ Better clarity and purity than others.Harsh Mariwala, chairman of the brand, was keen on maintaining its status and turning Parachute into a top brand. He identified these key points to bring in a change in the status quo at that time.âœ… Selling smaller packages for better sales: distributors in Nagpur and Vidarbha region were already selling Parachute oil in smaller packages. This boosted their sales and Harsh decided to take this move PAN India.âœ… Shifting from tin to plastic containers: Parachute was already a niche brand so to visualize it, Harsh proposed to shift to plastic containers. Plus, plastic was cheaper than tins. This, however, was resisted by retailers as they had seen the horrors of it before.Rats loved the smell of coconut oil and plastic containers attracted them. The square-shaped containers made it easy for rats to nibble at the edges which damaged the containers and the other products around it, causing losses for the retailers.To this, Mr Mariwala proposed a cylindrical plastic container which rats couldn't nibble at due to no edges and the coconut smell did not escape from the bottle due to the good quality material. He even went on to experiment to show that this new bottle did not attract any rats and got photos to prove his point.The retailers finally gave in and Parachute was then sold in the iconic blue teardrop-shaped bottle that we know of today.After making these significant changes in the product, the money saved from production was put into marketing campaigns to build public trust. And the rest is history.I think this is a great and inspiring story that shows us that:Quality product + innovative packaging + good marketing =  A success storyWhat is your take on this? What significance do you think packaging can hold for a product?#packaging #fmcg #retail #india #business
